translated: Furthermore, the bodhisattva practices the faculties of faith, diligence, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom, as well as the powers of faith, diligence, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom;
Furthermore, the bodhisattva practices the factors of enlightenment of mindfulness, investigation of dharmas, diligence, joy, lightness and fitness, concentration, and equanimity;
Furthermore, the bodhisattva practices right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.
This is the thirty-seventh.

As for the substance of these, the twenty-fifth verse of the Abhidharma-koÅ›a says, These are in reality only ten, referring to wisdom, diligence, concentration, faith, mindfulness, joy, equanimity, lightness, morality, and investigation as their substance.

First, wisdom includes eight, namely the four foundations of mindfulness, the faculty of wisdom, the power of wisdom, the factor of wisdom in the factors of awakening, and right view, taking wisdom as their substance.

Diligence also includes eight, namely the four right efforts, the faculty of diligence, the power of diligence, the factor of diligence in the factors of awakening, and right diligence, taking diligence as their substance.

Concentration also includes eight, namely the four bases of supernatural power, the faculty of concentration, the power of concentration, the factor of concentration in the factors of awakening, and right concentration, taking concentration as their substance.
Faith only includes two, namely the faculty of faith and the power of faith, taking faith as their substance.

Mindfulness only includes four, namely the faculty of mindfulness, the power of mindfulness, the factor of mindfulness in the factors of awakening, and right mindfulness, taking mindfulness as their substance.
Joy only includes one, namely the factor of joy in the factors of awakening, taking joy as its substance.
Abandonment only includes one, namely the factor of enlightenment of equanimity, which takes the essence of equanimity as its nature, not the abandonment of feeling.
Tranquility includes one, namely the factor of enlightenment of tranquility, which takes tranquility as its essence.
Restraint only includes three, namely right speech, right action, and right livelihood, which take restraint as their essence.
Reflection only includes one, namely right thought, which takes reflection as its essence.
Therefore, the thirty-seven [factors of enlightenment] only have ten essences.
Cultivating this contemplation, benefiting both oneself and others, as the Huayan Sutra says: All for the sake of not abandoning any sentient being, up to and including abiding in omniscience.
